title.narrative: Improvement and extension of the access to the potable water service in the Sahrawi refugee camps (Algeria)

description.narrative: In the Saharwi camps of Tindouf there are three independent water systems, namely: Zone 1 (Aaiun, Ausserd), Zone 2 (Smara, Boujador) and Zone 3 (Dakhla).The distribution of water is ensured through a water piped network (30%) and watertrucking (70%). SI-A is responsible for the piped network, composed of the following facilities: boreholes, reverse osmosis stations, chlorination stations, pumping stations, storage tanks, pipe network, taps and hoses. Supply takes place through taps fitted with an outlet to which a 150m flexible hose is attached to fill the 1 m3 family tanks.In the region of Tindouf, the only existing source of water is the underground water from two aquifers: Aquifer 1 has brackish water and provides water to Zones 1 and 2. This water requires a complex reverse osmosis treatment to decrease its hardness and its concentration of certain minerals like Sodium, Fluoride and Nitrate to acceptable levels, as established by the WHO. After this process, the water is disinfected by sodium hypochlorite, and it is then distributed to the camps. Aquifer 2 has non-brackish water and provides water to Zone 3, i.e. camp of Dakhla. This water is simply chlorinated before distribution.The limited access to water has a direct impact on the population's health and well-being. The investments made in the last 15 years have allowed to increase the availability of water, but it is still not enough in 3 out of 5 camps. In Zones 1 and 2, the need for osmosis process makes the achievement of minimum standards more difficult, since 30% of the extracted water is rejected in the process, thus decreasing the available amount for consumption.Other factors such as the population migration from one camp to another have modified the water needs on the ground; the camps of Smara and Boujador are becoming more important as they provide better opportunities to the population.
